abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Community School Support
            Project (CSSP) for Nepal were as follows: outcome was
            unsatisfactory; risk to development outcome was significant;
            Bank performance was unsatisfactory; and borrower
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Lessons learned
            include: community management of schools offers many
            potential benefits, but it is important to understand what
            communities of different educational and income levels are
            likely to implement. The education of the poorest children
            should not depend heavily on the means available to the very
            poor communities. Before scaling up pilot activities, it is
            important to evaluate those pilots using robust evaluation
            designs. In particular, Learning and Innovation Loans (LILs)
            should strive to create best practice in evaluation in order
            to maximize learning. Major educational reforms should be
            based on solid analytical work and take into account
            relevant research and evaluation from similar experiences
            elsewhere. There is little evidence that the design of the
            CSSP drew on research and evaluation findings of experiences
            with community management of schools, particularly as it
            relates to learning quality and outcomes, further
            compounding the lack of robust evaluation carried out under
            the LIL itself.

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile focuses on
            community management in Nepal which rekindled schooling.
            Nepal is a small, landlocked but relatively populous country
            in South Asia, with about 28 million people. By the early
            1950s the country had only twenty two high schools, of which
            twenty were community built, financed and managed. In 1972,
            however, the government took over more than 8,000 schools.
            But 30 years of neglect had taken a heavy toll. Literacy
            rates were 52 percent, compared to 58 percent in South Asia
            and 61 percent among low-income countries around the world.
            The International Development Association financed Community
            School Support Project was launched in 2003 to help reform
            the defunct public school system. Net primary enrollment
            rose from 84 percent in 2003 to 92 percent in 2008. Gender
            parity improved from 83 percent to 98 percent during the
            same period. More than 8,600 schools transferred back to
            community management for the transition in education sector.

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Community School Support
            Project for Nepal were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: strong political support is required to
            carry out public sector reforms of any kind. When the
            general public has lost confidence in the government's
            ability to provide services, a dramatic change is required
            because 'band aids' are insufficient to restore
            public confidence. Implementation of a project from within
            the established bureaucratic structure is more sustainable,
            even if there is weak institutional capacity. A project
            provides the opportunity to improve institutional capacity.
            Community-Managed School (CMS) require continuous support
            from government to sustain the reforms and to continue
            improvements in the quality of instruction. Intensive and
            hands-on approach is required for the long-term. School
            reform is contextual and is an evolutionary process
            requiring meaningful local participation and contribution.
            Functional partnership among key community partners
            (parents, influential persons, local Non-Governmental
            Organization (NGO), and school personnel) may take school
            reform to new heights and encompass new dimensions. The
            sense of ownership and a new feeling of responsibility
            generated by the transfer of school management to the
            community can lead to the institutional strengthening of the
            School Management Committee (SMC).

abstracts.cdata!:
The Community School Support Project
            will provide block, performance, supplementary, and other
            grants, including scholarships, and technical assistance
            (TA) for capacity building, to support communities taking
            over the management of government-funded schools. To this
            end, the project components will: 1) provide incentive
            grants for communities to manage schools funded by the
            Government, through block grants tied to performance of
            lower secondary, and secondary schools. In addition,
            performance grants will be provided for the improvement of
            access to primary education, and promotion rates, while
            supplementary grants would provide additional support to
            marginal communities, and encourage innovative approaches,
            such as bilingual education, and the employment of female
            teachers, and teachers from disadvantaged communities; 2)
            provide scholarships to out-of-school children in the first
            year, and maintenance scholarships in the later years of
            primary schools, provided to all children from poor
            households, expected to transform the social focus of
            communities, making the school a focal point for inclusion;
            3) support capacity building to assist communities, through
            non-governmental organizations and support organizations in
            school management. Moreover, Training for teachers will be
            provided in instructional planning and delivery, and in
            improving public relations with the community. Supportive
            orientation for civil servants, local government officials,
            and social workers will also be provided; and, 4) assist in
            the development of a monitoring and evaluation system in
            project coordination, within the existing monitoring and
            evaluation system of the Ministry of Education.
